Warning after four cases of bacterial meningitis in Nelson this year  The Nelson Mail

Public health officials are urging people to be alert to the symptoms of meningococcal disease in Nelson after four people have been diagnosed this year.

Scouts NZ warn parents of Northland meningococcal outbreak  Radio New Zealand

The organisers of a large Scout camp in Northland this summer are alerting scouts and their parents to the meningococcal disease outbreak in the region.

Toi Te Ora Public Health is advising Bay of Plenty and Lakes districts there is no change to meningococcal vaccination recommendations, in light of the outbreak ...

item.title: 'Anxious' parents paying for MenW vaccine - Northland doctor - Radio New Zealand
item.description:
'Anxious' parents paying for MenW vaccine - Northland doctor  Radio New Zealand

A Northland doctor says his practice is seeing dozens of concerned parents wanting to pay for their children to be vaccinated against meningococcal disease.

item.title: Northland met definition of meningococcal outbreak in October - New Zealand Herald
item.description:
Northland met definition of meningococcal outbreak in October  New Zealand Herald

Northland met the criteria for an outbreak of the virulent and deadly Meningococcal strain W in October, the Northland District Health Board says. The DHB says ...

A targeted vaccination programme will start in Northland next month to control an outbreak of meningococcal disease. Health Minister David Clark said advice ...

Vaccination no 'silver bullet' against meningococcal disease  Radio New Zealand

The national immunisation body says parents sometimes fear vaccinating their children based on anecdote and mistrust.

Lance O'Sullivan blasts health officials over handling of deadly meningococcal outbreak  Newshub

High-profile Northland doctor Lance O'Sullivan has unleashed on health officials over the handling of the deadly meningococcal outbreak. He says he's ...

item.description:

The Northland mother of seven-year-old Alexis Albert, who died of meningococcal disease in July, is urging parents not to hesitate when it comes to your child's ...

Fears grow over deadly meningococcal 'super-strain'  Otago Daily Times

A "super-strain" of meningococcal disease that's claimed six lives this year could become the dominant form in New Zealand if rates follow overseas trends, ...

item.title: Northland meningococcal response still too little, too late, says father - New Zealand Herald

Northland meningococcal response still too little, too late, says father  New Zealand Herald

The father of a man who died of meningitis in 2011 after ''a series of blunders'' at Whangārei Hospital is outraged the district health board failed to issue warnings ...

No outbreak of meningococcal in the Bay of Plenty but vaccine levels low  New Zealand Herald

An outbreak of meningococcal disease in Northland has some Bay of Plenty parents worried for their own children, but health officials say there is no change to ...

Meningococcal vaccine discussion for Northland after three deaths in the region  New Zealand Herald

The DHB and Ministry of Health could consider a funded meningococcal vaccine for Northland.

Northland DHB lobbying for meningococcal vaccination programme for 'some months'  New Zealand Herald

Northland DHB has been pushing for a vaccination programme against a deadly strain of meningococcal disease for "some months", according to an internal ...

Northland meningococcal outbreak 'a timely reminder' to Rotorua parents  New Zealand Herald

item.title: Northland girl dies of meningococcal disease six days after 7th birthday - New Zealand Herald
item.description:
Northland girl dies of meningococcal disease six days after 7th birthday  New Zealand Herald

Two purple footprints on a pink piece of paper are at the centre of a colourful wall of artwork and school certificates. The small footprints belong to 7-year-old ...

item.title: Warnings as deadly meningococcal disease strikes Bay of Plenty - New Zealand Herald
item.description:
Warnings as deadly meningococcal disease strikes Bay of Plenty  New Zealand Herald

Health authorities are warning of a national outbreak of fatal infectious disease.

item.title: Parents' plea to get meningococcal W shots on national schedule - ABC News
item.description:
Parents' plea to get meningococcal W shots on national schedule  ABC News

The parents of a Tasmanian toddler who recently contracted the deadly meningococcal W disease are sickened their son could have been immunised but they did not realise a vaccination existed. Photo: Arthur Long in good spirits as he recovers from the deadly infection. (Supplied) Carly and Nathan Long from Launceston in northern Tasmania are sharing their story in the hope of raising awareness about meningococcal and the increasing W strain. Their two-year-old son Arthur contracted the disease on February 26 this year, waking that Saturday morning with cold and flu-like symptoms. "He was just...

item.title: Too few U.S. teens getting flu and cancer vaccines - Reuters
item.description:
Too few U.S. teens getting flu and cancer vaccines  Reuters

By Lisa Rapaport (Reuters Health) - Less than half of U.S. adolescents get vaccinated to protect against seasonal influenza, and even fewer teens receive shots to help prevent cancers of the cervix and throat, new research suggests. “Immunization rates for teenagers are lower than for younger children who see the doctor more often,” said Dr. Henry Bernstein of Hofstra Northwell School of Medicine in Hempstead, New York. “Teenagers and their families need to recognize that they should get a physical every year and they should talk about vaccines at every visit,” Bernstein, lead author of two...

item.title: Perth baby's case prompts call for free meningococcal B vaccine - ABC News
item.description:
Perth baby's case prompts call for free meningococcal B vaccine  ABC News

Three years ago, Perth baby Robbie Buchan had his arms and legs amputated after contracting meningococcal B. Key points: - More than 200 people have contracted meningococcal in 2017, and 13 people have died this year - The Government currently only funds vaccinations for meningococcal C - Meningococcal B vaccine costs around $500 for a child under 12 months His parents said he never would have contracted the disease had the Federal Government offered free vaccinations against the deadly strain. Mother Desiree Scofield was shocked at the speed of Robbie's decline. "I couldn't understand how ...

item.title: Ballarat university student dies of meningococcal disease - ABC News
item.description:
Ballarat university student dies of meningococcal disease  ABC News

A 19-year-old university student has died after contracting meningococcal disease in Ballarat, west of Melbourne. What is meningococcal disease? - Acute bacterial infection which spreads through close human contact - Highest at-risk groups are infants, teenagers and young adults - Symptoms include headache, high fever, neck stiffness, sensitivity to light, vomiting, nausea - Simple precautions include washing hands, covering coughs and sneezes - Can lead to permanent disabilities or death in 24 hours, although majority of victims fully recoverSource: Meningococcal Australia, Department of H...

item.title: Student lost her legs and fingers after ‘common flu’ turned out to meningitis - The Independent
item.description:
Student lost her legs and fingers after ‘common flu’ turned out to meningitis  The Independent

A university student who thought she was suffering from the common flu lost both her legs and all the fingers on her left hand after her illness turned out to be a rare form of meningitis. Teenagers are the second biggest group at risk of contracting meningitis after toddlers and babies, with cases of the disease spiking during the winter months. But despite the Government’s introduction last August of a new bacterial meningitis vaccine for 17-18-year-olds and first year university students, research from charity Meningitis Now suggests only half of those eligible have received the injectio...

item.title: 'My heart and soul is shattered': Father's tribute to teen killed by new meningococcal strain - ABC News
item.description:
'My heart and soul is shattered': Father's tribute to teen killed by new meningococcal strain  ABC News

The father of a teenager who died from the deadly meningococcal disease says his "heart and soul is shattered" after the sudden loss of his son, as health authorities confirm he contracted the W strain, which is on the rise in Australia. West Australian Lloyd Dunham, 19, died while on holiday in Tasmania on Saturday after contracting a meningococcal infection. His father, Terry Dunham, has posted a moving tribute to his son on social media, amid an outpouring of grief from family and friends. External Link: Terry Dunham post to son "My heart and soul is shattered into pieces by your sudden ...

item.title: Vaccinations underway as meningitis kills hundreds in Nigeria - CNN
item.description:
Vaccinations underway as meningitis kills hundreds in Nigeria  CNN

A meningitis outbreak has killed 489 people in Nigeria this year, the World Health Organization said Thursday. The country's Center for Disease Control reported 4,637 suspected cases. Meningitis is a serious infection of the thin lining that surrounds the brain and spinal cord, which can cause brain damage. "Stereotype C," a new strain of meningococcal meningitis, emerged in Nigeria in 2013. Untreated, meningococcal meningitis, the bacterial form of the disease, is fatal in 50% of cases. The WHO also said that a vaccination campaign organized by the International Coordinating Group on Vacci...

item.title: Jeremy Hunt condemned by meningitis charity for making a ‘serious error of judgement’ - The Independent
item.description:
Jeremy Hunt condemned by meningitis charity for making a ‘serious error of judgement’  The Independent

A meningitis charity has condemned Jeremy Hunt for making a “serious error of judgement”, amid growing backlash over his advice to parents who suspect their children of having a rash. Meningitis Now, a charity formed in 1986 to fight the life-threatening disease, said that the Health Secretary’s suggestion – that parents could save time by searching online to determine the severity of their child’s rash – should be ignored. The intervention by the leading charity comes as doctors condemned Mr Hunt’s comments as “ludicrous” and “potentially fatal advice”. Medical professionals have also star...

item.title: Fight against meningitis lags behind other preventable diseases - The Telegraph
item.description:
Fight against meningitis lags behind other preventable diseases  The Telegraph

The fight against meningitis is lagging behind progress made against other vaccine-preventable diseases, a study has warned. There were over 2.8 million cases of meningitis in 2016 and nearly 320,000 people died from the disease - a 21 per cent reduction since 1990 - according to analysis published in The Lancet Neurology. But while this reduction is positive, it pales in comparison to progress made against other vaccine-preventable illnesses: deaths caused by measles, tetanus and diarrhoea have dropped by 93 per cent, 90 per cent and 58 per cent respectively over the same period. Meningiti...

item.title: 'Headache on Sunday, life support on Monday': Father welcomes Australian-first free vaccine - ABC News
item.description:
'Headache on Sunday, life support on Monday': Father welcomes Australian-first free vaccine  ABC News

Adelaide father and prominent real estate agent Oren Klemich knows what it's like to lose a son to meningococcal B. In 2009, teenager Jack Klemich succumbed to the disease just days after being admitted to hospital. "Perfectly healthy, [he] went to a party on a Saturday night, had a headache Sunday and was on life support Monday morning, and died soon after," Mr Klemich said. "It's a horrible illness, and had he got through it he probably would have been brain damaged." Since Jack's death, Oren Klemich has vocally campaigned to make meningococcal B vaccines more affordable for parents wanti...

item.title: After my friend died of meningitis during her first week at university, I investigated the disease killing so many students - The Independent
item.description:
After my friend died of meningitis during her first week at university, I investigated the disease killing so many students  The Independent

My friend Antonia was 18 years old when she died overnight from bacterial meningitis during her first term at Oxford University in October 2009. Nine years on from her death, there is still not enough being done to inform university students about the symptoms and dangers of the disease. Although many are aware that meningitis mainly affects babies and children, university students are the second most “at risk” group for the disease. One in four 15-19 year olds will be carrying the meningococcal bacteria at the back of their throats, compared to one in ten of the UK population. Sadly, stude...

item.title: Health regulator withholding vaccines results making it impossible to establish if drugs could be harmful - The Telegraph
item.description:
Health regulator withholding vaccines results making it impossible to establish if drugs could be harmful  The Telegraph

The failure of England's public healthy body to publish results of three major studies into vaccines for children makes it impossible for experts to establish whether the drugs could be harmful, scientists have claimed. Hundreds of children took part in three potentially risky Government drug trials, but Public Health England (PHE) breached the law by failing to add the findings to the official register set up to allow the scientific community to scrutinise the outcomes. Experts have accused PHE of an “incomprehensible” violation of the trust of parents who gave their consent for their chil...

item.title: Doctors' inconsistent meningitis advice putting children at risk, charity warns - The Independent
item.description:
Doctors' inconsistent meningitis advice putting children at risk, charity warns  The Independent

Up to half of children with bacterial meningitis are not diagnosed when they first see a doctor and charities are warning parents are too often sent home without advice to go straight to hospital if symptoms get worse. Recognising the early signs of meningitis can be extremely difficult as they are often similar to a cold flu or ear infection, however the infection can turn deadly within 24 hours, the Meningitis Research Foundation said. For this reason national guidelines state GPs and A&E staff should give “safety netting” advice to parents on how long a minor illness should last and what...

item.title: Students urged to get vaccinations after measles outbreak - The Guardian
item.description:
Students urged to get vaccinations after measles outbreak  The Guardian

New university students are being urged to ensure they have been vaccinated against measles following outbreaks of the highly infectious illness. Public Health England said students should check they are up to date with the MenACWY vaccine – which protects against meningitis – and the measles, mumps and rubella jab before the start of term. The number of European cases of measles has reached an eight-year high. Some students starting university this year may have missed out on the MMR vaccine as children, with uptake as low as 80% in 2003, PHE said. Related: Measles is on the rise in Europe...

item.title: Many doctors skip meningococcal vaccine talks with teens - Reuters
item.description:
Many doctors skip meningococcal vaccine talks with teens  Reuters

By Lisa Rapaport (Reuters Health) - Many pediatricians and family physicians don't discuss the meningococcal B vaccine with teens even though these conversations are recommended to determine whether adolescents should get shots to protect against this lethal infection, a U.S. study suggests. Just 51 percent of pediatricians and 31 percent of family physicians surveyed for the study said they "often" or "always" discussed the so-called MenB vaccine with teen patients. When they did discuss it, 91 percent of doctors recommended vaccination. Among participants who "never" or "rarely" discussed...

item.title: 30 minutes from death: Survivor of Meningococcal W strain wants you to get vaccinated - ABC News
item.description:
30 minutes from death: Survivor of Meningococcal W strain wants you to get vaccinated  ABC News

By Lily Mayers On Christmas night in 2017, Lily O'Connell went to bed thinking she had the flu. Forty-five minutes later, she was rushed to hospital and diagnosed with the Meningococcal W strain. "I turned the light on and I saw the rash on her face," Lily's mum Steph O'Connell said. The 23-year-old was in St Vincent's Hospital Intensive Care Unit for eight days and in hospital for three weeks. Lily credits her survival of the deadly disease to her mother's quick thinking. "Thankfully mum had a sixth sense," she said. "I think that's what saved me, that fast response." Lily said at that sta...

item.title: Woman dies of meningococcal disease in Northern Territory - ABC News
item.description:
Woman dies of meningococcal disease in Northern Territory  ABC News

A woman has died of meningococcal disease in the Northern Territory, the Department of Health has confirmed. The woman, from a remote Top End community, became unwell on July 31 and was airlifted to Royal Darwin Hospital, but died yesterday. A second woman in the urban Darwin area was also diagnosed with the disease, a spokesperson said, but has since made a full recovery and was discharged from hospital. The Department of Health said the women did not come into contact with each other and the cases were unrelated. Both women were diagnosed with the meningococcal W (MenW) strain. The Centre...

item.title: Meningococcal vaccine rollout to combat disease spike, Tasmanian Government confirms - ABC News
item.description:
Meningococcal vaccine rollout to combat disease spike, Tasmanian Government confirms  ABC News

By Rebecca Hewett Vaccines covering the A, C, W and Y meningococcal strains will be available free for under-21s in response to the five recent cases of the disease in Tasmania, the Government has confirmed. The Tasmanian Health Service announced there were in fact two new cases, making it five in less than two weeks. Health Minister Michael Ferguson said the rollout would be a "special expansion of our state-funded program", with the aim to "vaccinate every Tasmanian under the age of 21 and over 6 weeks old". He said the State Government would buy 100,000 vaccinations for dispensing over "...

item.title: Tasmanian parents vent their frustration at being kept in the dark about meningococcal cases - ABC News
item.description:
Tasmanian parents vent their frustration at being kept in the dark about meningococcal cases  ABC News

Hobart parents have slammed the State Government over the perceived secrecy about the growing number of cases of the potentially deadly meningococcal disease. Yesterday, after the ABC reported that the fourth case for the year had presented at the Royal Hobart Hospital without the public being made aware, the Tasmanian Health Service announced there were in fact two new cases, making it five in less than two weeks. New Town father of two Scott Plimpton said he felt the public was being kept in the dark. "Why should there be any secrecy about a public health issue?! I think [Health Minister]...

item.title: How can I protect myself from meningococcal disease? - ABC News
item.description:
How can I protect myself from meningococcal disease?  ABC News

By Carla Howarth There have been three cases of meningococcal disease in Tasmania in the past two weeks, leaving many people wondering what protective measures they can take for themselves and their families. We asked for your questions, added some of our own and put them to two experts — Tasmania's Director of Public Health Dr Mark Veitch, and Eliza Ault-Connell from Meningococcal Australia. Can I catch it from someone coughing on me? "The likelihood of it spreading short distances through the air or through more intimate contact is the main way in which it spreads," Dr Veitch said. But th...

item.title: Suspected meningococcal death prompts call for calm by health authorities - ABC News
item.description:
Suspected meningococcal death prompts call for calm by health authorities  ABC News

By Tamara Glumac Tasmania's Public Health Director is urging parents not to panic after the death of a Hobart teenager from a suspected meningococcal infection. Health authorities said laboratory results had shown evidence of meningococcal and further testing was being done to determine what strain of the disease it was. A small number of people who were in contact with the girl have been given antibiotics in case they are carrying the infection. But the Director of Public Health Dr Mark Veitch said linked cases were uncommon. "It's shocking and very unfortunate in the outcome for the perso...

item.title: Free flu shots for under 5s promised by SA Labor - ABC News
item.description:
Free flu shots for under 5s promised by SA Labor  ABC News

Children under five will be provided with free flu vaccinations, Labor has promised if re-elected this month in South Australia. Influenza is a prime reason young children end up in hospital, Premier Jay Weatherill said. "Influenza puts our kids at risk and places enormous strain on our hospitals," he said. Labor said $1.5 million would be spent to ensure all SA families with children aged between six months and five years can be vaccinated before the winter flu season. Health Minister Peter Malinauskas said hospital resources were under severe strain last winter. "Our hospital system was p...

item.title: Vaccines averted 4 mn cases of disease - Agenzia Ansa
item.description:
Vaccines averted 4 mn cases of disease  Agenzia Ansa

(ANSA) - Rome, February 16 - Vaccines averted four million cases of disease and thousands of deaths in the 115 years between 1900 and 2015, according to a report out Friday. The Higher Health Institute report assessed the impact of vaccines on diphtheria, tetanus, polio, hepatitis B, whooping cough, measles, mumps, scarlet fever, smallpox and meningococcus, finding that many of these had been "virtually eradicated". Italy's anti-vaccine movement objects to 10 compulsory vaccinations for school admission. The anti-establishment 5-Star Movement says the vaccinations should be recomme...

item.title: Boy, 5, dies of meningitis in La Spezia (3) - Agenzia Ansa
item.description:
Boy, 5, dies of meningitis in La Spezia (3)  Agenzia Ansa

(ANSA) - January 18 - A five-year-old boy died of meningitis in a hospital in La Spezia Thursday, the Liguria regional government said. Standard procedures for managing cases of meningococcus sepsis have been initiated, the government said. Anti-biotics will be given to all those who came into close contact with the boy this afternoon. Doctors will go to the boy's nursery school to start administering antibiotics, medical sources said. The regional health agency, ALISA, set up a commission to assess the case and recommend all possible action. Read the full article on ANSA English

item.title: Reason for fresh meningococcal W outbreak among Aboriginal children a mystery - ABC News
item.description:
Reason for fresh meningococcal W outbreak among Aboriginal children a mystery  ABC News

Doctors are investigating the cause of a fresh outbreak of the life threatening W-strain of meningococcal disease among Aboriginal children, prompting a fresh vaccination campaign in outback Western Australia. The WA Country Health Service [WACHS] has confirmed four cases of meningococcal W have been diagnosed in Kalgoorlie-Boulder, 600km east of Perth, in the past six months. The most recent of the cases, all of which involve Aboriginal children under the age of five, was reported to authorities last week. WACHS Goldfields public health physician Clare Huppatz said the outbreak was linked ...

item.title: Wedding bride dies from bacterial infection just hours after marrying the love of her life - The Independent
item.description:
Wedding bride dies from bacterial infection just hours after marrying the love of her life  The Independent

A young bride who became ill during her wedding ceremony has died just hours after marrying the love of her life. Jamieka Ngapera-McCarthy-Harford, from New Zealand, was struck with a bacterial infection linked to Meningococcal - a term used to describe both meningitis and septicaemia - just moments after she said her vows. Sadly, the 26-year-old died as a result of the bacterial infection shortly after. - Read more Parents share final pictures of son just before he died of meningitis Taking to Facebook with a heartwarming tribute, her mother, Linda McCarthy, posted an image of the newlywed...

item.title: Will your university student son or daughter bring meningitis home for Christmas? - The Telegraph
item.description:
Will your university student son or daughter bring meningitis home for Christmas?  The Telegraph

When Shirali Patel took up her place at Churchill College, Cambridge, last September, she threw herself into university life as well her studies. It was only when she returned to the family home at the end of her first term in December that the 19-year-old A* student from Harrow began feeling unwell. “I just felt really tired, like I had a bad cold with a sore throat,” Shirali says. “My dad took me to our family GP who took my temperature, checked my throat, and told me to take paracetamol and rest. There really were no warning bells, no extreme or unusual symptoms, so I took his advice. I ...

item.title: Like peeling your skin off: What happens when you contract meningococcal - ABC News
item.description:
Like peeling your skin off: What happens when you contract meningococcal  ABC News

After five days of agonising pain, Eliza Bradley says it was a young medical student who delivered the diagnosis that saved her life. The 30-year-old Kalgoorlie woman had been admitted to Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital in Perth in September 2016, after succumbing to what appeared to be a mystery infection. In the space of hours, the mine worker had gone from enjoying a barbecue with friends to having those same friends rush her to hospital, to waking up in intensive care and being asked if she was an organ donor. "I was in there for five days waiting to be prepped for surgery, but they hadn'...

item.title: Deadly new meningococcal strain claims another young life - ABC News
item.description:
Deadly new meningococcal strain claims another young life  ABC News

A young Perth woman has died from meningococcal disease, the latest in a wave of infections that has seen almost twice the number of meningococcal cases in 2017 compared to last year. The Health Department says the latest victim — a woman in her 20s — is the fifth person to die from the new W strain of the disease this year. Meningococcal W strain What you need to know about the W strain of meningococcal. The woman's family does not want to reveal any details, but her work colleagues at a government department were informed following her death last week. A Health Department spokesman said t...

item.title: Meningococcal W death prompts vaccination update plea - ABC News
item.description:
Meningococcal W death prompts vaccination update plea  ABC News

Health advocates have called on the Federal Government to update its vaccination schedule to include protection from a deadly strain of meningococcal disease which has killed at least 10 people this year, following the death of a young Western Australian woman. The Perth woman was the fifth person to die of meningococcal in the state this year. She was infected by the deadly W strain, which made up 35 per cent of the 271 cases reported across Australia up to September. Now health advocates say the Federal Government must consider updating its vaccination schedule to cover four strains — A,C...

item.title: Child dies of meningococcal disease in Perth - ABC News
item.description:
Child dies of meningococcal disease in Perth  ABC News

A young child has died from meningococcal disease in Perth while two other people have been diagnosed with the condition. The health department said of those two patients, one was a child who was recovering while the second was an adult visitor who had returned interstate after being treated. The cases were not linked, the department said, but provided no further information about them. There have now been four deaths from meningococcal disease in WA this year. All were infected with type W. Meningococcal disease is on the rise in WA again after decreasing dramatically from a peak of 86 cas...
